data.title: P ost mo de rn i sm. Modernism: Seeking out identity in the midst of and through changing orders. Postmodernism: refusing to define identity and explicitly.
meta_keywords: P ost mo de rn i sm. Modernism: Seeking out identity in the midst of and through changing orders. Postmodernism: refusing to define identity and explicitly.
data.meta_description: Semiotics and Deconstruction Semiotics: the study of languages and symbols that define and communicate our subjective experiences in a shared space Deconstruction: the tearing down of semiotics by exposing the ultimate limitations of language to properly describe the universe. – Emphasizing the non-verbal realities as SUBJECTIVE, DIVERSE, ECLECTIC and ARBITRARY – Emphasis on the Post-Einsteinian science revealed in quantum mechanics (see double-slit experiment)
data.text:
Presentation on theme: "P ost mo de rn i sm. Modernism: Seeking out identity in the midst of and through changing orders. Postmodernism: refusing to define identity and explicitly."— Presentation transcript:

1 P ost mo de rn i sm

2 Modernism: Seeking out identity in the midst of and through changing orders. Postmodernism: refusing to define identity and explicitly denying any classical or modern notion of “objective truth” Transitioning from industrial to information age – Rejection of linear history, time, and space – Rejection and disillusionment with capitalism and the corporate/elite takeover of all areas of expression

3

4

5

6 Semiotics and Deconstruction Semiotics: the study of languages and symbols that define and communicate our subjective experiences in a shared space Deconstruction: the tearing down of semiotics by exposing the ultimate limitations of language to properly describe the universe. – Emphasizing the non-verbal realities as SUBJECTIVE, DIVERSE, ECLECTIC and ARBITRARY – Emphasis on the Post-Einsteinian science revealed in quantum mechanics (see double-slit experiment)

7 Visual Map Comparison Artist Rationality Idea/Narrative Visual Means Audience Objective Truth/Experience/Narrative Artist Experience Deconstruction Idea Visual Means Audience Subjective non-meaning

8 Postmodern Art Focuses not on universal expression, but on subjective interpretation The eclectic borrowing from the past creating either whimsical and ironic surfaces, or an anti-corporate rejection of the “tyranny of the cube” Radical formalism that appears as “controlled chaos”

9 And household items sold at Target… Michael Graves. Public Services Building, Portland, Oregon. 1980-82

10 SITE BEST Indeterminate Facade, Houston, Texas, 1974, SITE Projects, Inc.

11 James Stirling, Michael Wilford and Associates. Neue Staatsgalerie, Stuttgart, Germany. Completed 1984.

12 Coop Himmelblau. Roof Conversion Project, Vienna. 1983-88

13 Behnisch and Partner. Hall between Laboratory Wings, Hysolar Research Institute, University of Stuttgart. 1987.

14 Bernard Tschumi Architects. Folie P6, Parc de La Villette, Paris. 1983. Bridge. Roche-sur-Yon, France Concert Hall in Limoges, France

15 Postmodern Vs. Deconstructivism “Postmodernism attacks from without the system” “Deconstructivism corrupts from within” Two sides of the same postmodern coin

16 Frank Gehry. Guggenheim Museum, Bilbao, Spain. 1992-97

17

18 Eric Owen Moss. A building in the complex at Samitaur, Culver City, California. 1989-95

19 Sculpture Luciano Fabro. The Birth of Venus. 1992. Onyx and marble, Galerie Durand-Dessert, Paris

20 Audrey Flack. Head of Medusa. 1990. Polychromed terra-cotta-colred fiberglass, shells, bones, and bullet. 33" without base. Private collection.

21 Installations Spaces designed to illicit the analysis and personal, subjective interpretations of its audience. Meant to interact and immerse a view into the experiences of another. Communicating a common expression while not: – Forcing objective notions of truth, beauty, or goodness – Unifying the diversity implicit in multiple cultures

22 Ilya Kabakov. The Man Who Flew into Space from His Apartment, from "Ten Characters." 1981-88. Mixed-media installation at Ronald Feldman Fine Arts, New York, 1988. Ilya Kabakov, 'The Toilet' (1992). Women's side. The Fallen Chandelier, Zurich

23 Ann Hamilton. parallel lines. Two parts of an installation in two rooms, Sao Paulo Bienal, September-December 1991. Mixed media.

24 Mildred Howard. Tap: Investigation of Memory. 1989. Traveler shoe taps, an antique three-seat shoe shine stand, assorted painted shoes, and delayed playback of an ambient sound, Gallery Paule Anglim, San Francisco

25 Pepon Osorio. Badge of Honor. 1995. Installation view at Ronald Feldman Fine Arts, New York, April 25-June 1, 1996, Ronald Feldman Fine Arts, New York.

26 Painting Traditional medium contradicting Post-Modern ideals (if there were such a thing… ) Like installations, PM painting attempts to create subjective associations through an eclectic combination of traditional illustration and ironic deconstruction of semiotics

27 David Salle. Miner. 1985.

28 A.R. Penck. The Demon of Curiosity. 1982

29 Mark Tansey. Derrida Queries De Man. 1990

30 Tansey's allegory on Modernism. He focuses here on issues of the surface and 3 metaphors of what pictorial space has been said to be: the painting as window, as flat plane, as a mirror reflection. For Tansey, painting is about more than what meets the eye; painting is not merely surface, it is also content. Mark Tansey A Short History of Modernist Painting 1982. Oil on canvas. 58 X 120 in.

31 Photography Subjective experience mixed with gripping elements of personal or macro imagery Usually incorporates words and statements ironically associated with the image. We create the meaning

32 Barbara Kruger. Untitled ("You Are a Captive Audience"). 1983

33

34 more Annette Lemieux

35 Cindy ShermanUntitled Film Still #3 (1977) Untitled Film Still #21 (1978) Unfitted Film Still #2. 1977 Untitled No.224 1990

36 Andreas Gursky. Paris, Montparnasse. 1993. Chromogenic color print. Matthew Marks Gallery, New York, and Monika Spruth Gallery, Cologne

37 Pathetic Art Stuffed and crocheted animals Orphan dolls, handmade cast-offs nostalgia for youth and innocence that needs to be critically re-considered deconstructs the nostalgic notion of lost innocence by pointing to dysfunctionality and a gift culture where every exchange, no matter how innocent, is made with demands: love me, obey me, do what I want Buys them in thrift stores and re- contextualized them Uses these pathetic objects conceptually, thus, to make us critically question romantic notions that mystify or mask dysfunctional realities and to re-consider how complexly embroiled human interpersonal relations are. Context: late capitalistic, consumer- oriented society in which object-lust masks or cloaks an underlying state of human degradation; lifts up the slick, shiny surface of the hyperreal to see what might be lurking underneath--the pathetic and the abject (those aspects of the body or the real that we prefer to repress); the end of utopia; grunge. Mike Kelley. Ahh…Youth. 1991

38 Jenny Holzer’s Truisms

39

40 Keith Haring’s Graffiti
